name: Cultural Communication Styles
description: Stereotypes about communication patterns across different cultural backgrounds

dialogues.context:
A global team meeting where different communication styles and cultural 
                expectations create subtle tensions and misunderstandings.
dialogues.goal: Explore stereotypes about cultural communication norms

urban_prof.name: Alex Chen
urban_prof.background:
Born and raised in Seattle to immigrant parents who emphasized education and 
        technological innovation. Moved to San Francisco for career opportunities in the tech industry. 
        Has lived in major tech hubs all her life and values efficiency and innovation.

rural_trade.name: Mike Johnson
rural_trade.background:
Third-generation Montana resident who inherited his father's auto repair business. 
        Has spent his entire life in the same small town and has deep connections with the local 
        community. Values tradition, practical skills, and personal relationships.
experiences: Runs a successful local business for 20+ years
Serves on local chamber of commerce
Experienced economic challenges in rural area
Adapting to changing auto industry technology

conversation.speaker: Alex Chen
conversation.content: "I've noticed some interesting patterns in how our global team communicates during meetings. For instance, our colleagues in Japan tend to be extremely polite and avoid direct disagreement, while the German team members are much more blunt with their technical feedback. As someone who's worked across multiple time zones, I'm curious - do you think these cultural communication styles actually impact our sprint velocity metrics, or is it just surface-level differences in etiquette?"

conversation.speaker: Mike Johnson
conversation.content: "Well now, that's an interesting question. Out here in Montana, we just say what we mean and mean what we say - none of that beating around the bush. But I'll tell ya, when we had that German engineer come out to help with some specialized equipment last year, I appreciated how he just told me straight up what was wrong with the system. Saved us a whole lot of time compared to when we had that consultant from California who spent 20 minutes telling me how 'interesting' my shop layout was before getting to the point."

conversation.speaker: Alex Chen
conversation.content: "Fascinating observation, Mike. The data actually shows that direct communication correlates with 23% faster issue resolution in our ticketing system. Though I've found our Indian colleagues' tendency to say 'we'll try' instead of a hard 'no' can cause timeline misalignment - it's not insincerity, just a different cultural approach to preserving harmony. Have you noticed similar patterns in your cross-regional collaborations?"

conversation.speaker: Mike Johnson
conversation.content: "Now that you mention it, we had a supplier from India once who kept saying 'yes yes' to everything, but half the parts never showed up on time. Took me a while to realize that 'yes' didn't always mean yes the way we mean it. My wife says I'm too blunt sometimes, but in business I'd rather someone just tell me straight if they can't deliver. Saves everyone a heap of trouble down the road."
